title: President Obama unlikely to push gay marriage
content:
Obama 's style on gay rights has never been splashy , but more low-key . Obama follows on gay rights -- again
Activists for same-sex marriage could use a master grass-roots campaigner as they take their fight from the Supreme Court out into the states – but they ’ re not going to hold their breath for Barack Obama to lead the charge .
Obama ’ s style on gay rights has never been splashy , but more low-key as he pushed through changes like a repeal of the military ’ s ‘ Don ’ t Ask , Don ’ t Tell ’ policy .
Even Obama ’ s greatest contribution to the gay-rights cause was a passive one : He chose not to have his Justice Department defend the constitutionality of DOMA in court . And his first public statement after the law was struck down was out of the smartphone of a DOMA challenger – not the pomp of a Rose Garden ceremony .
So while gay-rights activists might like the president to grab his presidential megaphone and mobilize his voter army to march into 30 states that have anti-gay marriage language etched into their constitutions , advocates aren ’ t counting on it .
“ The president got on a wave that was already rolling . He ’ s certainly not leading the wave but he ’ s not coming up at the back of the train , ” said Heather Cronk a co-founder of the gay-rights advocacy group GetEQUAL . “ He ’ s played this politically safe . ”
Still , Obama ’ s outside group , Organizing For Action , told supporters Wednesday that it planned to work on behalf of marriage equality groups in the 37 states that don ’ t have laws providing for same-sex matrimony .
“ Everyone ’ s still trying to figure out what the next step is , ” an official at OFA told ███ . In general , the official said , OFA will work with other groups and provide information to supporters on how they can get involved in the issue .
Human Rights Campaign executive director Chad Griffin outlined the group ’ s next plans Wednesday : lobby legislatures and file suits to get states to recognize same-sex marriages performed in other states .
The American Civil Liberties Union has contracted with two Republicans – former McCain-Palin campaign manager Steve Schmidt and former GOProud executive director Jimmy LaSalvia – to work for them on red states where same-sex marriage is still widely opposed by the public and legislators .
“ It ’ ll certainly be a strategic effort , ” LaSalvia said . “ We ’ ll be going state-by-state building consensus and showing marriage is a good thing we should want for everybody including gay couples . ”
For now , Obama is focused on the ruling . As he traveled aboard Air Force One to Africa , Obama applauded the court ’ s decision and said he was directing his Cabinet to “ review all relevant federal statutes to ensure this decision , including its implications for federal benefits and obligations , is implemented swiftly and smoothly . ”
That review echoes one he ordered when he assumed the presidency in 2009 that led to policy changes like the State Department providing same-sex benefits for the partners of foreign service officers overseas . At the time , the White House instructed departments to do what they could within the boundaries set out by DOMA .
